case_vignette: the patient is a 46-year-old woman who presents at your primary care office for an examination with a single lesion that appears on her left arm. during the examination, it is revealed that the patient has a large sclerotic, indurated, hyperpigmented, anhidrotic, and hairless plaque on the right dorsal forearm. the patient states that these lesions had previously been slightly pink for several months before they had turned brown in color and had become “hard.” the patient has type 2 diabetes, but she has no other medical problems. in addition, she has no relevant social or family history.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a large, hard, brown spot on my right forearm that doesn't sweat and has no hair.
How long have you had the spot on your forearm?
The spot has been on my forearm for several months; it was slightly pink initially and turned brown later.
Have you experienced any changes in sensation in the area around the spot, like numbness or tingling?
No, I haven't experienced any changes in sensation, numbness, or tingling around the spot.
Does this spot itch, and have you noticed it growing or changing in any way?
No, the spot does not itch, and I haven't noticed it growing or changing recently.
Do you have any personal or family history of skin diseases or cancers?
No, I do not have any relevant personal or family history of skin diseases or cancers.
Have you had any recent trauma or injury to that area of your forearm before noticing the spot?
No, I have not had any recent trauma or injury to that area of my forearm before noticing the spot.
Final Diagnosis: Nevus anelasticus
